intro: Sisyrinchium sellowianum, commonly known as the golden-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Iridaceae and is characterized by its slender, grass-like stems and showy yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, while its flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences. Sisyrinchium sellowianum is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its bright, long-lasting blooms.
